THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 20.
COMMEMORATION DAY
James Bryce, D. C. L., British Ambassador to the United States, Delivers
Oration and Receives Degree
of Doctor of Laws.

With all the ceremonial pomp
possible to an institution, which can
boast of a past but little exceeding
a generation—a period of time
which not even in this country suffices for the flowering of tradition—thel-ohns Hopkins University
celebrated its thirty-fifth anniversary on Commemoration Day. The
occasion was perhaps the most bri:liant in the history of the University. The ceremonies were held in
the Lyric Theatre. The stage upon
which so many Hopkins students
had recently tripped to the light
tunes of "Professor Napoleon" was
converted into a palm-enframed
amphitheatre for the enthronement
of grave professors.
At x i o'clock the ceremonies began. The procession of those who
were to participate in the exercises
entered. The marshal, Dr. Edward
B. Matthews,led the way. Next followed President Remsen, and the
venerable orafor of the day, gorgeous in the insignia of the University of Oxford; the mayor of the
city; the dean; the chaplain; and,
lastly, the long line of the faculty,
whose hoods and gowns displayed
the various colors of all the principal universities of the world. The
procession moved upon the stage
and was seated, and after a prayer
by the chaplain, Rev. J. Ross Stevenson, the president introduced the
orator.
Mr. Bryce is in person beginning
to show the marks of age. His
voice, however, is still strong and
clear and his utterance is graceful
and fluent. He chose for his subject one of the most vital questions
to higher education today—the conflict between specialization and latitude of culture. He began by remarking the gceat influence which
the Hopkins has had in giving to
university training in the Englishspeaking countries the direction
which it now pursues; and he then
referred to some of the obvious
faults into which that direction has
led. Specialization in some particular department of human knowledge, he remarked, is absolutely
necessary to the student of today.
The present problem is how to reconcile such specialization with
scholarly broad-mindedness. He indicated a course of studies which he
thought would procure such a result, and would at once convince the
scientist that many things, being
mutable and transient, cannot be
subjected to permanent laws, and
the student of the humanities on the
other hand, that certain facts are

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 27, 1911.
fixed and definite. After all, he said,
knowledge in one particular specialty seldom proves of any pi actical
use unless other knowledge of a
widely different variety can be
brought to bear upon it to form a
novel combination. When Mr.
Bryce had concluded his address he
was presented for the degree of
doctor of laws by Prof. Westel W.
Willoughby in a brief speech of
praise. The degree was duly conferred by President Remsen.
The second speaker of the day.
was Mr. B. Howell Griswold, chairman of the committee on endowment and extension, and within the
last few days elected a trustee of
the University. In a highly facetious
and graceful manner Mr. Griswold sketched the methods which
the committee had employed in collecting the recent million dollar fund
and the success with which they had
been met. His freauent sallies were
roundly applauded by the audience,
and the faculty joined in heartily
when he remarked that "large sums
of money are things known to Hopkins professors chiefly by hearsay."
When Mr. Griswold had done reporting on the collection of the fund
Mr. R. Brent Keyser, president of
the board of trustees, briefly detailed the plans for its distribution.
Contracts will be let in the immediate future, he stated, for the erection of Gilman Memorial Hall at
Homewood. When this building is
under way, work on a new McCoy
Hall will be commenced; two or
more laboratory buildings will be
erected as soon as possible; and it
may be confidently expected that
the freshmen class which enters the
Hopkins next autumn will be graduated from the new university at
Homewood.
A change in the. management of
the Hospital was announced by
President Remsen, and Judge
Henry Harlan was called upon to
relate the details. Dr. Henry M.
Hurd, Judge Harlan announced, for
twenty-two years superintendent of
the Hospital, had handed in his
resignation, which had been acceoted. An agreement had been reached whereby Dr. Hurd was to continue his connecton with the institution as secretary of the Hospital
and adviser to the board of trustees,
and the superintendency had been
accepted by Dr. Wilfred M. Smith.
A native of Maine and a young
man, Dr. Smith received his degree
of A. B. at Bowdoin College in
1899. Tn 1903 he received the degree of M. D. at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School. He became an interne and afterward resident gynecologist at Lakeside Hospital,
Cleveland, Ohio. Later he was connected with the Health Department

DR. HOWELL HONORED

ALUMNI BANQUET

Banquet in His Honor Is Given at the
Belvedere—His Portrait Painted and
Presented to University.

Dr. Kirby F. Smith Elected President
for Ensuing Two Years — Alumni
Council Representatives Chosen.

• On Tuesday evening a banquet
was given at the Belvedere in honor
of Professor Howell, who recently
resigned as dean of the Medical
School. In the gathering were men
who had made their mark in medicine; who had won recognition, not
only in Baltimore as men of medical
science, but nationally; who paid
honor to the man the force of whose
influence they had felt.
As an enduring memorial to him
his friends desired to mark the
event in some way. It was accordingly decided that Cecilia Beaux,
the noted artist, be commissioned to
paint his portrait for the Universit,r.
The portrait, which is an excellent resemblance, was presented to,
the University at the banquet by
Dr. Reid Hunt, a former student of
Dr. Howell, connected with the
Marine Hospital at Washington. It
will be placed in McCoy Hall.
The portrait was admired by
the large gathering, and when it
was presented the University Dr.
Remsen gracefully thanked the students who had given it, declaring
that it would be placed in McCoy
Hall, in the midst of the group of
men who became famous when associated with Johns Hopkins.
The banquet was arranged by Dr.
William H. Welch, assisted by Dr;.
John J. Abel, F. P. Mall, S. J, Meltzer, W. S. Halstead, R. H. Chittenden and Dr. R. Hooker.

The Alumni banquet was givea
at the Belvedere Hotel, Wednesday
evening.
Dr. J. Whitridge Williams, dean
of the Medical School and president
of the Alumni Association, acted as
toastmaster, and just as he finished
announcing the results of the election of officers Ambassador Bryce
entered the hall. All present immediately arose, and, amid prolonged
cheers, the Ambassador was escorted to a seat at the speakers' table.
Dr. Williams then finished announcing the election results, which
was as follows:
President, Kirby F. Smith, Ph.
D., 1889; secretary, William Sherman Bansemer, A. B., 180r,; treasurer, Horace Edgar Flack, Ph. D.,
1906; members of the executive
committee,'to serve for two years,
Paul J. Dashiell, A. B., 1887; R.
Curzon Hoffman,
A. B., 1903;
George C. Morrison,
Jr.,. B., Ph. D.;
George L. Radcliffe, A. B, 1897,
Ph. D., 1900; Morris A. Soper, A.
B., 1893.
' Dr. Smith will serve as president
for two years. Dr. Williams also
announced the results of the election to the Alumni Council. These
were: From the Ph. D. group, Dr.
E. R. L. Gould, of New York city;
from the M. D. group, Dr. J. Hall
Pleasants, of Baltimore; from the
A. B. group, Allan McLane, of Baltimore; at-large, Dr. W. Franklin
Willoughby, assistant director of
Census, Washington, D. C. All of
the amendments to the constitution,
including the one providing for the
publication of an alumni magazine,
were passed by large majorities.
Before he introduced the speakers, Dr. Williams made a few brief
remarks concerning the raising of
the Homewood fund. He said that
the A. B.'s of the university had
contributed the most per capita;
that the Ph. D.'s were next, and
that the doctors of medicine the
least.
Ambassador Bryce was then introduced and made a happy speech to
his "fellow alumni," as he called
those present. He said that he
thought he was the youngest alumnus of the University, having received •his degree in 1911, and that
he wished now to thank the authorities for the honor which they had
conferred upon him.
Mr. Levering elicited a veritable
storm of applause when he turned
to Mayor Mahool and expressed the
hope that he would be mayor for

Georgetown Meet.

In the track meet, which takes
place next Saturday at Georgetown,
Hopkins will be well represented.
Although there are only eleven men
going down, each one is expected
to be a point winner. Horrax, who
landed two firsts at the armory,
hopes to turn the trick again in
Washington. Lee and Reeside
ought to finish well up in the mile,
and it would not be astonishing if
one or the other broke the tape first.
It will be remembered that Tappan
won the pole vault at the armory
by a good margin and, as he is in
fine form, he is nearly sure to be
placed at least in that event next
Saturday. In the 440-yard dash
four Hopkins men are entered, and
of these two,,at least, should get
places.
Don't forget the Hullabaloo benefit tomorrow night!
There will be a meeting of the Athletic Board on Monday, March 6.

This fall Hopkins will at last be
given an opportunity to play football teams of first rank. A great
deal of emphasis has been laid upon
the •fact that the schedule is
a hard one and that the football team must have the sup-.
port of every undergraduate and
graduate in order to pull through
successfully. But we cannot repeat
it too often. The Navy game, as
everyone knows, is the first of the
season. If we do not want to be
• swamped and disgraced forever we
must begin practice at least two
weeks earlier. , It is absolutely
necessary, on penalty of certain
failure, to lay the plans now for
the fall practices. But it isn't
enough merely to appoint early
practices. The practices must be
attended, and regularly too, by
every member of the squad. This
is a vital matter, and it should be
taken seriously to heart by every
student.

The Johns Hopkins University
Library receives regularly 2,500
periodicals and serial publications.
Fifteen hundred of these are received in exchange for its own pub-,
lications.

The,interest, which was but recently manifested, in the Arbitration Society seems to have flagged
to a considerable extent. It is not
possible to have at every meeting
a speaker of the calibre of Dr.
Mead or Mr. Scott. But the meetings which are taken up by discussions from the members of the
society are even more important.
Only in this way can an interest in
the peace movement be stimulated.
It is when a man gets to work and
studies a problem himself that he
gets interested in it. Therefore,
let every member of the Society be
present at the meeting on Wedneslay. We have a reputation to sustain.

The Medical School has been
closed until further notice.

A good reputation is quickly lost
and but slowly regained. This
statement can be vouched for by
each of the four banquet committees. Even now, three years after
the memorable "smash-up" at the
Carrollton, the men most interested
in the welfare of the china have
been loath to serve Hopkins classes.
It has taken a long time to restore
confidence in us. Therefore, we
are glad to see that the freshmen
and the sophomores have come to
an amicable understanding in regard to their banquets, and we hope
that this may mark the end of the
annually recurring feuds, which so
frequently marred otherwise gentlemanly behavior.

THE NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 27, 1911
SENIOR BANQUET

COMMUNICATIONS

Fine Speeches and Lots of Fun — A
Reunion to Be Held in Five Years.

February 23, 191 I.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

AS I hear that you are willing to

print letters which may be of interest to Hopkins men, I would like to
tell of an incident which occurred
at the Commemoration Day exercises which I should be sorry to see
occur again.
After Ambassador Bryce began
to speak, about seven or eight of the
ushers came and sat down in the last
row, making a great deal of noise
and disturbance. And from then
on, during all the remainder of
exercises, they sat there making
would-be jokes and laughing and
talking so that no one around could
hear a word the speaker was saying. After about fifteen minutes
of this, a gentleman sitting in front
of them turned around and asked
them if they would mind being
quiet.
Instead of complying, however,
they simply began making "jokes"
at the gentleman's expense. Finally,
at the end, when Dr. Remsen was
making the announcements, they
became louder than ever, so that the
gentleman, evidently in desperation,
asked them again to be quiet. But
to no purpose.
After the exercises were over, as
he was, going out, I heard him remark td a lady and gentleman :
"Well, I certainly am ashamed that
I ever graduated from the Johns
Hopkins when I come to a meeting
like this and see what ill-mannered
fellows they now have to,put in positions of honor. Why, do you
know, that every one of those -fellows had on an usher's badge and
that the head usher was among
them! Yours truly,
"SPEcTAToR."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

The debate preliminaries this
week have shown us that in spite
of a great deal of talent present
among us the greater number of
students appear indifferent to any
literary activities. It is a shame
that not more than four men contested for places on the senior team.
There should have been seven or
eight men out any way. It pleases
me to think that if we adopted some
of the customs prevalent in most
other American colleges and universities, that this trouble might,be
rectified to a certain extent. For
instance, why cannot we have a literary society here. Such an association would be of great use in
many ways. Different works of
literature might be discussed and
we might exchange ideas on various
subjects in a way that it is not possible amidst the petty gossip of the
basement barber shop between
classes. The spirit of debate, too,
might be fostered and the candidacy for the Varsity debating team
would not be restricted to a mere
handful. Discussion of the matter
would be welcomed by
A DEBATER.

The Seniors helcl their banquet
last Thursday evening at the New
Howard Hotel. It was an unusually successful affair, and exceeded
by far the expectations of even the
most sanguine. Every one of the
speeches was good, and the speakers said things that were worth
while, quite an unusual occurrence
at a class banquet. The thought
that this was the last banquet made
the men rather serious, but things
were lively enough in spite of this.
In the absence of "Stoney," Eddie
Hulburt spoke on athletics. In the
course of his remarks he used a
metaphor, which will, no doubt, become classical. He was . speaking
of the gradual rise of the athletic
spirit at Hopkins and its triumph
over all obstacles. "Like a turtle
it crawled from its retirement.
Then, spreading its wings, it soared -." Eddie sat down. The
other speeches wer all partly serious, partly humorous. Harry Lindell remarked that the subject of
his toast, "Class Spirit," was very
large, and since he was a little fellow it would be difficult for him to
cover it. Reaney 'Wolfe spoke
about reunions, and urged the necessity of sticking together. Upon
his sugestion a vote was taken, and
McCabe, Stockett, and Murray appointed as a committee to see that a
reunion was held February 23,
1916. Every member of the class
is to be notified.
The banquet was splendid, and
thanks is due to the committee for
their care in its arrangement.

THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 20.
COMMEMORATION DAY
James Bryce, D. C. L., British Ambassador to the United States, Delivers
Oration and Receives Degree
of Doctor of Laws.

With all the ceremonial pomp
possible to an institution, which can
boast of a past but little exceeding
a generation—a period of time
which not even in this country suffices for the flowering of tradition—thel-ohns Hopkins University
celebrated its thirty-fifth anniversary on Commemoration Day. The
occasion was perhaps the most bri:liant in the history of the University. The ceremonies were held in
the Lyric Theatre. The stage upon
which so many Hopkins students
had recently tripped to the light
tunes of "Professor Napoleon" was
converted into a palm-enframed
amphitheatre for the enthronement
of grave professors.
At x i o'clock the ceremonies began. The procession of those who
were to participate in the exercises
entered. The marshal, Dr. Edward
B. Matthews,led the way. Next followed President Remsen, and the
venerable orafor of the day, gorgeous in the insignia of the University of Oxford; the mayor of the
city; the dean; the chaplain; and,
lastly, the long line of the faculty,
whose hoods and gowns displayed
the various colors of all the principal universities of the world. The
procession moved upon the stage
and was seated, and after a prayer
by the chaplain, Rev. J. Ross Stevenson, the president introduced the
orator.
Mr. Bryce is in person beginning
to show the marks of age. His
voice, however, is still strong and
clear and his utterance is graceful
and fluent. He chose for his subject one of the most vital questions
to higher education today—the conflict between specialization and latitude of culture. He began by remarking the gceat influence which
the Hopkins has had in giving to
university training in the Englishspeaking countries the direction
which it now pursues; and he then
referred to some of the obvious
faults into which that direction has
led. Specialization in some particular department of human knowledge, he remarked, is absolutely
necessary to the student of today.
The present problem is how to reconcile such specialization with
scholarly broad-mindedness. He indicated a course of studies which he
thought would procure such a result, and would at once convince the
scientist that many things, being
mutable and transient, cannot be
subjected to permanent laws, and
the student of the humanities on the
other hand, that certain facts are

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 27, 1911.
fixed and definite. After all, he said,
knowledge in one particular specialty seldom proves of any pi actical
use unless other knowledge of a
widely different variety can be
brought to bear upon it to form a
novel combination. When Mr.
Bryce had concluded his address he
was presented for the degree of
doctor of laws by Prof. Westel W.
Willoughby in a brief speech of
praise. The degree was duly conferred by President Remsen.
The second speaker of the day.
was Mr. B. Howell Griswold, chairman of the committee on endowment and extension, and within the
last few days elected a trustee of
the University. In a highly facetious
and graceful manner Mr. Griswold sketched the methods which
the committee had employed in collecting the recent million dollar fund
and the success with which they had
been met. His freauent sallies were
roundly applauded by the audience,
and the faculty joined in heartily
when he remarked that "large sums
of money are things known to Hopkins professors chiefly by hearsay."
When Mr. Griswold had done reporting on the collection of the fund
Mr. R. Brent Keyser, president of
the board of trustees, briefly detailed the plans for its distribution.
Contracts will be let in the immediate future, he stated, for the erection of Gilman Memorial Hall at
Homewood. When this building is
under way, work on a new McCoy
Hall will be commenced; two or
more laboratory buildings will be
erected as soon as possible; and it
may be confidently expected that
the freshmen class which enters the
Hopkins next autumn will be graduated from the new university at
Homewood.
A change in the. management of
the Hospital was announced by
President Remsen, and Judge
Henry Harlan was called upon to
relate the details. Dr. Henry M.
Hurd, Judge Harlan announced, for
twenty-two years superintendent of
the Hospital, had handed in his
resignation, which had been acceoted. An agreement had been reached whereby Dr. Hurd was to continue his connecton with the institution as secretary of the Hospital
and adviser to the board of trustees,
and the superintendency had been
accepted by Dr. Wilfred M. Smith.
A native of Maine and a young
man, Dr. Smith received his degree
of A. B. at Bowdoin College in
1899. Tn 1903 he received the degree of M. D. at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School. He became an interne and afterward resident gynecologist at Lakeside Hospital,
Cleveland, Ohio. Later he was connected with the Health Department

DR. HOWELL HONORED

ALUMNI BANQUET

Banquet in His Honor Is Given at the
Belvedere—His Portrait Painted and
Presented to University.

Dr. Kirby F. Smith Elected President
for Ensuing Two Years — Alumni
Council Representatives Chosen.

• On Tuesday evening a banquet
was given at the Belvedere in honor
of Professor Howell, who recently
resigned as dean of the Medical
School. In the gathering were men
who had made their mark in medicine; who had won recognition, not
only in Baltimore as men of medical
science, but nationally; who paid
honor to the man the force of whose
influence they had felt.
As an enduring memorial to him
his friends desired to mark the
event in some way. It was accordingly decided that Cecilia Beaux,
the noted artist, be commissioned to
paint his portrait for the Universit,r.
The portrait, which is an excellent resemblance, was presented to,
the University at the banquet by
Dr. Reid Hunt, a former student of
Dr. Howell, connected with the
Marine Hospital at Washington. It
will be placed in McCoy Hall.
The portrait was admired by
the large gathering, and when it
was presented the University Dr.
Remsen gracefully thanked the students who had given it, declaring
that it would be placed in McCoy
Hall, in the midst of the group of
men who became famous when associated with Johns Hopkins.
The banquet was arranged by Dr.
William H. Welch, assisted by Dr;.
John J. Abel, F. P. Mall, S. J, Meltzer, W. S. Halstead, R. H. Chittenden and Dr. R. Hooker.

The Alumni banquet was givea
at the Belvedere Hotel, Wednesday
evening.
Dr. J. Whitridge Williams, dean
of the Medical School and president
of the Alumni Association, acted as
toastmaster, and just as he finished
announcing the results of the election of officers Ambassador Bryce
entered the hall. All present immediately arose, and, amid prolonged
cheers, the Ambassador was escorted to a seat at the speakers' table.
Dr. Williams then finished announcing the election results, which
was as follows:
President, Kirby F. Smith, Ph.
D., 1889; secretary, William Sherman Bansemer, A. B., 180r,; treasurer, Horace Edgar Flack, Ph. D.,
1906; members of the executive
committee,'to serve for two years,
Paul J. Dashiell, A. B., 1887; R.
Curzon Hoffman,
A. B., 1903;
George C. Morrison,
Jr.,. B., Ph. D.;
George L. Radcliffe, A. B, 1897,
Ph. D., 1900; Morris A. Soper, A.
B., 1893.
' Dr. Smith will serve as president
for two years. Dr. Williams also
announced the results of the election to the Alumni Council. These
were: From the Ph. D. group, Dr.
E. R. L. Gould, of New York city;
from the M. D. group, Dr. J. Hall
Pleasants, of Baltimore; from the
A. B. group, Allan McLane, of Baltimore; at-large, Dr. W. Franklin
Willoughby, assistant director of
Census, Washington, D. C. All of
the amendments to the constitution,
including the one providing for the
publication of an alumni magazine,
were passed by large majorities.
Before he introduced the speakers, Dr. Williams made a few brief
remarks concerning the raising of
the Homewood fund. He said that
the A. B.'s of the university had
contributed the most per capita;
that the Ph. D.'s were next, and
that the doctors of medicine the
least.
Ambassador Bryce was then introduced and made a happy speech to
his "fellow alumni," as he called
those present. He said that he
thought he was the youngest alumnus of the University, having received •his degree in 1911, and that
he wished now to thank the authorities for the honor which they had
conferred upon him.
Mr. Levering elicited a veritable
storm of applause when he turned
to Mayor Mahool and expressed the
hope that he would be mayor for

Georgetown Meet.

In the track meet, which takes
place next Saturday at Georgetown,
Hopkins will be well represented.
Although there are only eleven men
going down, each one is expected
to be a point winner. Horrax, who
landed two firsts at the armory,
hopes to turn the trick again in
Washington. Lee and Reeside
ought to finish well up in the mile,
and it would not be astonishing if
one or the other broke the tape first.
It will be remembered that Tappan
won the pole vault at the armory
by a good margin and, as he is in
fine form, he is nearly sure to be
placed at least in that event next
Saturday. In the 440-yard dash
four Hopkins men are entered, and
of these two,,at least, should get
places.
Don't forget the Hullabaloo benefit tomorrow night!
There will be a meeting of the Athletic Board on Monday, March 6.

This fall Hopkins will at last be
given an opportunity to play football teams of first rank. A great
deal of emphasis has been laid upon
the •fact that the schedule is
a hard one and that the football team must have the sup-.
port of every undergraduate and
graduate in order to pull through
successfully. But we cannot repeat
it too often. The Navy game, as
everyone knows, is the first of the
season. If we do not want to be
• swamped and disgraced forever we
must begin practice at least two
weeks earlier. , It is absolutely
necessary, on penalty of certain
failure, to lay the plans now for
the fall practices. But it isn't
enough merely to appoint early
practices. The practices must be
attended, and regularly too, by
every member of the squad. This
is a vital matter, and it should be
taken seriously to heart by every
student.

The Johns Hopkins University
Library receives regularly 2,500
periodicals and serial publications.
Fifteen hundred of these are received in exchange for its own pub-,
lications.

The,interest, which was but recently manifested, in the Arbitration Society seems to have flagged
to a considerable extent. It is not
possible to have at every meeting
a speaker of the calibre of Dr.
Mead or Mr. Scott. But the meetings which are taken up by discussions from the members of the
society are even more important.
Only in this way can an interest in
the peace movement be stimulated.
It is when a man gets to work and
studies a problem himself that he
gets interested in it. Therefore,
let every member of the Society be
present at the meeting on Wedneslay. We have a reputation to sustain.

The Medical School has been
closed until further notice.

A good reputation is quickly lost
and but slowly regained. This
statement can be vouched for by
each of the four banquet committees. Even now, three years after
the memorable "smash-up" at the
Carrollton, the men most interested
in the welfare of the china have
been loath to serve Hopkins classes.
It has taken a long time to restore
confidence in us. Therefore, we
are glad to see that the freshmen
and the sophomores have come to
an amicable understanding in regard to their banquets, and we hope
that this may mark the end of the
annually recurring feuds, which so
frequently marred otherwise gentlemanly behavior.

THE NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 27, 1911
SENIOR BANQUET

COMMUNICATIONS

Fine Speeches and Lots of Fun — A
Reunion to Be Held in Five Years.

February 23, 191 I.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

AS I hear that you are willing to

print letters which may be of interest to Hopkins men, I would like to
tell of an incident which occurred
at the Commemoration Day exercises which I should be sorry to see
occur again.
After Ambassador Bryce began
to speak, about seven or eight of the
ushers came and sat down in the last
row, making a great deal of noise
and disturbance. And from then
on, during all the remainder of
exercises, they sat there making
would-be jokes and laughing and
talking so that no one around could
hear a word the speaker was saying. After about fifteen minutes
of this, a gentleman sitting in front
of them turned around and asked
them if they would mind being
quiet.
Instead of complying, however,
they simply began making "jokes"
at the gentleman's expense. Finally,
at the end, when Dr. Remsen was
making the announcements, they
became louder than ever, so that the
gentleman, evidently in desperation,
asked them again to be quiet. But
to no purpose.
After the exercises were over, as
he was, going out, I heard him remark td a lady and gentleman :
"Well, I certainly am ashamed that
I ever graduated from the Johns
Hopkins when I come to a meeting
like this and see what ill-mannered
fellows they now have to,put in positions of honor. Why, do you
know, that every one of those -fellows had on an usher's badge and
that the head usher was among
them! Yours truly,
"SPEcTAToR."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

The debate preliminaries this
week have shown us that in spite
of a great deal of talent present
among us the greater number of
students appear indifferent to any
literary activities. It is a shame
that not more than four men contested for places on the senior team.
There should have been seven or
eight men out any way. It pleases
me to think that if we adopted some
of the customs prevalent in most
other American colleges and universities, that this trouble might,be
rectified to a certain extent. For
instance, why cannot we have a literary society here. Such an association would be of great use in
many ways. Different works of
literature might be discussed and
we might exchange ideas on various
subjects in a way that it is not possible amidst the petty gossip of the
basement barber shop between
classes. The spirit of debate, too,
might be fostered and the candidacy for the Varsity debating team
would not be restricted to a mere
handful. Discussion of the matter
would be welcomed by
A DEBATER.

The Seniors helcl their banquet
last Thursday evening at the New
Howard Hotel. It was an unusually successful affair, and exceeded
by far the expectations of even the
most sanguine. Every one of the
speeches was good, and the speakers said things that were worth
while, quite an unusual occurrence
at a class banquet. The thought
that this was the last banquet made
the men rather serious, but things
were lively enough in spite of this.
In the absence of "Stoney," Eddie
Hulburt spoke on athletics. In the
course of his remarks he used a
metaphor, which will, no doubt, become classical. He was . speaking
of the gradual rise of the athletic
spirit at Hopkins and its triumph
over all obstacles. "Like a turtle
it crawled from its retirement.
Then, spreading its wings, it soared -." Eddie sat down. The
other speeches wer all partly serious, partly humorous. Harry Lindell remarked that the subject of
his toast, "Class Spirit," was very
large, and since he was a little fellow it would be difficult for him to
cover it. Reaney 'Wolfe spoke
about reunions, and urged the necessity of sticking together. Upon
his sugestion a vote was taken, and
McCabe, Stockett, and Murray appointed as a committee to see that a
reunion was held February 23,
1916. Every member of the class
is to be notified.
The banquet was splendid, and
thanks is due to the committee for
their care in its arrangement.
